At 22:24 06/12/2005, Colin wrote:
>Ian Badcoe wrote:


>Ok so I provide a GType, PType and FitnessType and it's up to the coder
>supplying the types to provide 3 types that are compatible with each
>other. So if a GType decodes itself into a PType that the FitnessType
>doesn't understand then does this get detected at compile time or does
>it result in a runtime exception?

In C++ it's a compiler error, just like passing any wrong type to a function.

That's kinda the strength of templates over subclassing.

The weakness of templates, is, of course:

C:\Framework\Develop\jsKernel\parser\oCatMan.cpp(1625) : error C2664: 
'void __thiscall std::map<long,class CoCatalogue *,struct 
std::less<long>,class 
std::__default_alloc_template<1,0> >::erase(struct 
std::_Rb_tree_iterator<struct std::pair<long const ,class CoCatalogue 
*>,struct std::pair<long const ,class CoCatalogue *> &,struct 
std::pair<long const ,class CoCatalogue *> *>)' : cannot convert 
parameter 1 from 'struct std::_Rb_tree_iterator<struct 
std::pair<short const ,int>,struct std::pair<short const ,int> 
&,struct std::pair<short const ,int> *>' to 'struct 
std::_Rb_tree_iterator<struct std::pair<long const ,class CoCatalogue 
*>,struct std::pair<long const ,class CoCatalogue *> &,struct 
std::pair<long const ,class CoCatalogue *> *>'
         No constructor could take the source type, or constructor 
overload resolution was ambiguous

:)

         Ian

In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
